data.title: indentation of multiple var definitions should follow alignment of first line
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:1.1.2
- OS Version:Ubuntu 17.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. use one var, let or const declaration to define multiple names on multiple lines
2. auto-indent all lines in the declaration

VSCode indents the line as follows
```javascript
const onevar = 1,
twovar = 2;
```

the indentation should (I think) look like below (emacs' js2-mode indents this way),
```javascript
const onevar = 1,
      twovar = 2;
```

data.title: Persistent result view for Find All References
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.14393

I'm trying to explore the code in a large (~25000 LOC) TypeScript file, and it gets a little confusing when you're only able to look at the find references result for a single function at a time. I had two feature requests:

 - Would it be possible to give users the option to disable the code-attached Find References result window and simply display it as a fixed pane somewhere?
 - Would it be possible to display a history of Find References searches and their results? Something similar to Notepad++'s find results:

![Notepad++ find results](https://ldzfpw.by3302.livefilestore.com/y4mqGe8s5zgmKkAVaIZgSe7QPIdPU1Lc_G9GUWbSOxKg_Dh2LC_iYXfxI88ZyfmbrA6Ptcya2OTsTolCUn7gxFj7NS0N4cvImTr6IDf0fTfRpqwKUMXeXS9BiIcGK0PbXiWLAxnl7LQZpyISjioeU-gWBGrclX4xG_XCM2xRVWgRHpgAAqv4tLt-PDW5Z0hZda_LGCmGhOtWnNaSYljKgYUlg/2017-04-23_19-20-34.gif?psid=1)

A more general solution to the problem would be some kind of symbol explorer that lets you inspect the complete reference graph of any symbol, however this might be prohibitively expensive given how the language server protocol works.

data.title: Lightbulb Gets in the Way of Breakpoint
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.11.2 - OS Version: macOS 10.12.4 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Try to set a breakpoint by clicking in the margin area Expected outcome: breakpoint can easily be set Actual outcome: lightbulb icon sitting in the margin "blocks" the breakpoint from being set Note: I'm pretty sure the lightbulb used to "float" out in the editor area when activated, and that was fine, but at some point, it was moved into the margin area. I find this is frustrating when in the midst of an intense debugging session.

data.title: Add greying out of unactive C/C++ pre-processor block
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

This is a feature request about the C/C++ developement workflow

Visual Studio proper grey out non active preprocessor block (that doesn't meet the #if or #ifdef conditions) 

Here a screenshot of Visual Studio 2017 on a Windows box. The macro `_WIN32` is defined here:

![devenv_2017-04-23_03-44-55](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1816251/25309813/65048a42-27d7-11e7-831a-4a2510803dfb.png)

Visual Studio Code doesn't handle this functionality at all, here's the same code as shown by VSCode, on a Linux box (`_WIN32` not defined. `__linux__` defined) : 

![screenshot_2017-04-23_03-48-58](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1816251/25309842/d1264710-27d7-11e7-8dc0-233d25b8916f.png)

(the syntax highlighting is also broken, this bug was reported by issue #25198)

data.title: Source Control Spinner No Longer Animates
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.11.2 - OS Version: macOS 10.12.4 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a project that has source control enabled 2. Make some changes, save them, and commit them 3. Click the circular spinner icon Expected outcome: spinner icon animation plays when push is occurring Actual outcome: spinner icon animation no longer plays I think this stopped working with the April release. It's not mission critical by any means, but I miss it.

data.title: Cloud version (electron-less)
data.body:
May be is a very naive question, but since electron is basically a chromium browser and a nodejs server is it possible to run vscode without the chromium broser part, just the node server and then access it via a separate chrome/chromium browser?

That will be very helpful to do development in remote machines (self-hosted cloud development).

I know electron provides some integrations with the host os. For example: file operations  (File menu) and window manager operations ( View menu). Can they be bypassed  anyhow? Only the file operations will be needed, the window management ones I guess they won't be needed.

data.title: Incorrect tool-tip and definition path for import statements in js file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.2 (6eaebe3b9c70406d67c97779468c324a7a95db0e, 2017-04-13T08:03:11.395Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|xml|DotJoshJohnson|1.7.0|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.9.3|
|java|redhat|0.1.0|
|html-preview-vscode|tht13|0.1.1|
|cordova-tools|vsmobile|1.2.7|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone https://github.com/reactjs/react-redux (edit: and run `npm install`)
2. Open the new repo folder with vscode.
3. Edit the file src/components/connectAdvanced.js.
4. Hover your mouse pointer over the string `'invariant'` on the line that says `import invariant from 'invariant'`.
5. Press F12 or otherwise activate the `Go to definition` command.

In step 4, I expected to see a tool-tip displaying the path to my local `node_modules` directory inside of my repo. Instead, I was shown a path to the global `node_modules/@types` directory on my system.

Likewise in step 5, when I pressed F12 vscode opened a `index.d.ts` instead of opening the local `node_modules/invariant/index.js` file.

Knowing the types that vscode is using to display Intellisense is not really useful to me because they almost never match the version of the code that I'm actually working with. I would **strongly** prefer to at least be able navigate to the actual implementation easily instead of to the `.d.ts` definition file.

Thank you.

data.title: Drag and drop from FTP folder in explorer into editor DELETES the file on FTP server

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T20:59:05.375Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Not sure if this is a bug in the explorer or VS Code, but when I open an FTP site in the Windows Explorer and drop a file into the editor, not only does it not open it (would be too good), but the file vanishes from the FTP site, as if it was moved somewhere (just that nothing happens in the editor, no feedback at all). 

The problem is most certainly a wrong drop-action-feedback to the windows explorer (Move action). 
However, one does NOT expect this behaviour and is pretty shocked when the file is suddenly lost, especially if one did not backup it before (which one rarely does before opening it).

data.title: Ctrl+C does not stop node server in external Command Line
data.body:
From a normal Windows command prompt, `ctrl+c` will stop a node server running.

However, if I start the command prompt via the `VS Code` menu item `Open in Command Prompt`, then pressing `ctrl+c` (even multiple times) does not stop the server as usual.

Running on Windows 10 x64
VS Code 1.11.2

Also asked on SO:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/43531894/ctrlc-does-not-stop-node-server-in-command-line-from-vs-code

data.title: Test column breakpoints in node2
data.body:
Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-chrome-debug-core/issues/144

Complexity: 2

**OS**
- [x] Any - @alexandrudima 

- This only works in Node 8, but not too recent of a build, because you'll encounter https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/12364. This build will work: https://nodejs.org/download/nightly/v8.0.0-nightly201703249ff7ed23cd/

Verify:
- You can set column BPs with shift+f9
- The BPs go to a reasonable column and the debugger stops in that spot
- You can set multiple column BPs on a line

If it seems like the BP ends up on a weird column, you can check with Chrome devtools. The blue marks inline are valid BP locations.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/25307722/c0729158-275a-11e7-9fcd-267fa7b0a25f.png)


Also test with Node < 8. The column BP behavior is kind of undefined there. Sometimes a BP will go to the next line or a confusing spot, just based on what v8 decides to do. But we have to detect whether it supports a certain API so just sanity check it that you don't see errors or totally broken behavior.

data.title: Prominently indicate whether an editor or the panel has focus
data.body:
This is a feature request.

I keep catching myself starting to type a terminal command while it's the editor that currently has focus. When the focus is on the sidebar, this is easy to see ‚Äî for example, selected file is white-on-blue, or the search box has blue border. I think there should be a similarly prominent visual indication of focus being on an editor or on the bottom panel.

PS To anyone having the same issue ‚Äî I think setting

    "terminal.integrated.cursorBlinking": true,
    "terminal.integrated.cursorStyle": "block"

 should mitigate this a bit.

data.title: Key bindings not working in embedded syntaxes as expected
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

This issue could be connected to [Issue 25154](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/25154)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Download code from https://github.com/Hugibeer/RhetosDSL 
2. Open Rhetos.vscode folder in VSCode and start the extension
3. Open file Samples\SampleTest.rhe and at line 5 run command Toggle line comment. Line 5 is inside double quotes, adn should be treated as SQL, thus line comment should be "--", and not "//"

Is this maybe a configuration issue? Or does VS Code not differ completely where it should use Rhetos like comment (//) from SQL comments (--)?

Thanks you.

data.title: Wrong IntelliSense with `chalk` package
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Linux Ubuntu 16.04

I'm using `chalk` package and I found if my variable is for e.g. `string`, I get these suggestions.

![screenshot from 2017-04-22 14-02-44](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10441177/25303883/b133de68-2764-11e7-9be7-cf009ef4f133.png)

As you can see in picture I get mixed suggestions with `chalk` i. e. `bgRed` and with normal JS suggestions i. e. `charAt`, I don't know how but they mixed and it's bad, because it's impossible to use these properties/functions in strings. **I also noticed it's the same in TypeScript files, not only JS files.** VS Code need to provide only built-in functions.

My `jsconfig.json`:
```
{
  // Specifies a list of files to be excluded.
  "exclude": [
    "dist",
    "node_modules"
  ]
}
```

P.S. As I said this happens to TypeScript files also.
